description: The Harvard EdCast is a weekly series that features a 15-20 minute conversation with thought leaders in the field of education from across the country and around the world. Hosted by Matt Weber, the Harvard EdCast will serve as a space for educational discourse and openness, focusing on the myriad issues and current events related to the field.
title: The Harvard EdCast

episodes.title: Teaching Across a Political Divide
episodes.description: America seems more divided than ever. Paula McAvoy, an assistant professor at North Carolina State University, has long focused her work on helping educators teach young people how to live together in this world. Educators can use the recent presidential election as a tool. In this episode of the EdCast, McAvoy discusses how to make the most of your "political" classroom.

episodes.title: Applying Education Research to Practice
episodes.description: Education research is often disconnected from the reality of practitioners in the field. Carrie Conaway, a senior lecturer at Harvard and an expert on how to apply education research in practice, gets into the details of how to bridge the gap between education research and practice. In this episode, she discusses the way education leaders can use existing education research and also begin to implement their own evidence-based research to figure out what works.

episodes.title: How Colleges Fail Disadvantaged Students
episodes.description: In this encore episode of the Harvard EdCast, which originally aired on February 13, 2019, Tony Jack discusses the consequences of conflating access and inclusion — and the barriers that low-income students face when they get to college -- a situation even more important in the wake of campus closures due to COVID.

episodes.title: How Covid-19 Impacts Rural Schools
episodes.description: We don't often hear about the 15% of students who attend rural schools. It seems this population is often left out of national conversations about the impact of COVID on education. Mara Tieken, an associate professor at Bates College, is an expert on rural schools and has been helping many rural school districts cope throughout the pandemic. In this episode, Tieken talks about some of the ways rural schools are getting through the pandemic and ideas on how to include rural schools in the national conversation.

episodes.title: Education in Uncertain Times
episodes.description: Times are troubling for many higher education institutions around the country. With many enrollments down and huge drops in student applications for federal financial aid, it's not just institutions struggling but low-income college goers are facing major disruptions as well. Bridget Terry Long -- the dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education and an economist -- is concerned about every student and how the pandemic may impact their education and futures. In this episode, she speaks candidly about the many challenges facing higher education institutions, college goers, and what it's like to lead an institution during a pandemic.

episodes.title: The Role of Education in Democracy
episodes.description: Many people question the state of democracy in America. This is especially true of young people, who no longer share the same interest in democracy as the generations before them. Harvard's Danielle Allen has long studied what citizens need in order to succeed in democracy and how our social studies and civics education can impact this. In this episode, Allen discusses how we got where we are today, the unique role of education, and what it takes to reinvest in education for democracy.

episodes.title: Making Online Learning Work
episodes.description: With many children learning remotely this fall, Sal Khan, founder of Khan Academy – a leader in online learning – knows that it’s a daunting task for everyone involved to deliver the best and most high quality experience. In this episode of the EdCast, Khan shares some of the most effective teaching strategies for remote learning, and how parents can help support online learning at home. He also gives practical tips for how to manage teaching young children online.

episodes.title: Improving College Access for Native People
episodes.description: Only about 14 percent of Native Americans attend college and many often leave before graduating. TaraJean Yazzie-Mintz has spent much of the past three decades working to improve access to education for Native people. In this episode of the Harvard EdCast, she addresses the barriers to higher education for Native people, and how higher education institutions can do a better job at welcoming and keeping Native people in this space.

episodes.title: The Digital Divide and Remote Learning
episodes.description: The pandemic set off a race for schools to launch remote learning and to keep children from falling behind. But at what cost? In this episode of the EdCast, Harvard Lecturer Uche Amaechi discusses the tension that exists for schools trying to find a balance between continuing education in equitable ways among all students.

episodes.title: School Leadership During a Crisis
episodes.description: With more than 55 million children out of school due to the pandemic, school leaders are facing the adaptive challenge of all time. The challenges go far beyond closures. Harvard Professor Deborah Jewell-Sherman shares what is on the minds of school leaders throughout the country, and advises how they can stay grounded and plan in such a difficult time.

episodes.title: Schooling for Critical Consciousness
episodes.description: What is the role of schools in teaching students, especially students of color, how to face oppression and develop political agency? Are there ways that some educators succeed in doing this in one school but not in another school? Professors Daren Graves and Scott Seider were eager to find the answers and set out to research five mission-driven high schools over four years. In this episode of the EdCast, they share the ways that educators and school leaders can help young people better understand and challenge racial injustices.

episodes.title: The Benefits of Family Mealtimes
episodes.description: Despite family meal times being hugely beneficial to kids, only about 30% of families manage to eat together regularly. Anne Fishel, executive director of the Family Dinner Project, knows it's not always easy to find that time but it also doesn't have to be so hard. Through her work, she helps families find fun, creative, and easy ways to make meals a reality. As many families adjust to stay-at-home orders from the Coronavirus, there is a silver lining in that now there is time to enjoy a family meal or two.

episodes.title: Learning Loss and the Coronavirus
episodes.description: With many schools closed around the country due to the Coronavirus, educators and parents may have growing concerns about how long students can go without formal instruction. Jennifer McCombs, a senior policy researcher for the RAND Corporation, has long studied the effects of summer break on learning -- particularly for at risk students from low-income families or students performing below grade level. In this episode of the EdCast, McCombs discusses how what we know from summer learning loss might guide educators, districts, and parents as they set forth on learning when school is closed.

episodes.title: College Students in the Age of Surveillance
episodes.description: This newest generation of college students know that algorithms tend to skew the truth online, but many feel it is par for the course. Alison Head, a researcher and director of Project Information Literacy, explores how algorithmic-driven platforms are shaping the ways college students access news and information and its potential to change the college landscape.

episodes.title: Schools, Families, and the Coronavirus
episodes.description: Many school districts are facing challenging decisions about how to prepare and respond to the novel Coronavirus including whether to close and try distance learning. Harvard Epidemiologist Bill Hanage and Education Ethicist Meira Levinson explore the public health issue and its potential impact on schools and families. They also offer guidance for practitioners and parents.

episodes.title: Racial Differences in Special Education Identification
episodes.description: Harvard Lecturer Laura Schifter explains disproportionality and why so many students of color are placed in special education, often in separate classrooms from their peers. While income status is sometimes accepted as the reason behind this phenomenon, Schifter says that doesn't tell the full story. In this EdCast, Schifter shares recent research into this issue and discusses the challenges facing special education.

episodes.title: Getting Beyond the Literacy Debate
episodes.description: There's much debate in the literacy world about what's the best way to teach children to read. With two out of three children struggling to learn to read, the nation is questioning what actually works. Harvard Professor James Kim discusses why learning to read is so challenging and shares how his latest model called MORE offers another way.

episodes.title: The Pitfalls of Oversharing Online
episodes.description: Children aren't the only people compromising their privacy online. Grown ups are also taking to to digital media and technology, and oversharing information about the children in their lives too. Leah Plunkett, a law professor and parent, wants adults to think twice before talking about children online. In this episode of the Harvard EdCast, Plunkett, author of "Sharenthood: Why We Should Think Before We Talk About Our Kids Online," discusses all the way adults -- including educators -- overshare details about children and how to take steps to safeguard their actions.

episodes.title: Grading for Equity
episodes.description: When Joe Feldman, author of Grading for Equity, looked closer at grading practices in schools across the country, he realized many practices are outdated, inconsistent, and inequitable. Today he helps educators develop strategies that tackle inconsistent grading practices. In doing so, Feldman tells the Harvard EdCast how shifting grading practices can change the landscape of schools and potentially the future for students.

episodes.title: The Common and Yet Hidden Language Disorder
episodes.description: Although more children have developmental language disorder (DLD) than autism -- most people have never heard of it. Dr. Tiffany Hogan, the director of the Speech and Language Literacy Lab at MGH Institute, wants greater awareness of this language disorder, especially among educators and parents. In this episode of the Harvard EdCast, she discusses what DLD is and how it can affect children's learning ability.

episodes.title: Unconscious Bias in Schools
episodes.description: Many educators struggle with unconscious bias in their roles at school -- often in ways that can unknowingly perpetuate racism and negatively affect students. In this episode of the EdCast, Tracey Benson and Sarah Fiarman offer ways to address these issues directly and outline how educators can start this work in their schools. Benson, an assistant professor at University of North Carolina at Charlotte, and Fiarman, director of leadership development at EL Education, are authors of the new book, Unconscious Bias in Schools.

episodes.title: Sticker Shock: The Actual Cost of College
episodes.description: When many people see the college price tag, they believe it's financially out-of-reach. But Wellesley College Professor Phillip Levine, who studies college affordability, says that people often don't realize there's a difference between the price of college and what a family might actually pay. Through the development of Myintution.org -- an online tool that helps families uncover the actual cost -- he hopes more students will achieve their college dreams.

episodes.title: What Test Scores Actually Tell Us
episodes.description: Harvard Professor Andrew Ho thinks test scores can often simplify how we view student performance, school effectiveness, and educational opportunity. By taking a more comprehensive look at data like test scores and learning rates in districts, we may be able to better identify and contextualize how well a school is doing beyond just average test scores. In this episode of the Harvard EdCast, Ho discusses his work with the Educational Opportunity Project at Stanford University and how it provides data to help scholars, policymakers, educators, and parents learn how to improve educational opportunity for all children.

episodes.title: Colleges as Courageous Spaces
episodes.description: Many college and university leaders recognize the importance of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) work being done on their campus, but that doesn't always mean it's done for the right reasons. In this episode of the Harvard EdCast, Richard Reddick, associate dean for equity, community, engagement and outreach at the University of Texas at Austin, discusses the rise of DEI work in higher education and how this work should create more courageous spaces on college campuses.

episodes.title: Prioritizing Student Mental Health in College
episodes.description: Students are struggling with mental health issues on college campuses. Dr. Stephanie Pinder-Amaker, a founding director of McLean Hospital's College Mental Health Program in Massachusetts, says there's a lot of things we can all do to help the college mental health crisis. Pinder-Amaker discusses the factors leading to mental distress on campus, how colleges can create better responses, and really how everyone plays an important role in this issue, especially what happens long before students get to college.

episodes.title: Why We Need to Rethink Recess
episodes.description: Sociologist Rebecca London knows recess is an afterthought in many schools day. Too often, it's just seen as a break or a way to get some physical exercise for kids. She wants to see educators rethink how to use that time to better support young students. In this episode of the EdCast, London shares ideas from her new book, "Rethinking Recess," how to create a more inclusive recess, and why taking away recess -- especially as punishment -- is a bad idea for kids.

episodes.title: Higher Education's Biggest Conundrums
episodes.description: David Wilson used college as a path out of poverty. Now, as the president of Morgan State University in Baltimore, he wants that to be the reality for other children too. But, for so many kids today, getting to college and paying for college is a challenge. After 25 years in higher education leadership, President Wilson grapples with issues of access for students every day. In this episode of the EdCast, he talks about why this is a pivotal time to change higher education and how to tackle issues of rising costs associated with college.

episodes.title: Facing Challenges, Driving Success (in Chicago)
episodes.description: Dr. Janice K. Jackson knew taking the role as CEO of the Chicago Public Schools would be challenging. She has inherited a history of problems in the district, but refuses to make her leadership about the blame game. In this episode of the EdCast, she discusses how she's facing the challenges before her. Even with a teacher strike looming, Jackson's pragmatic leadership and "We'll get through it" attitude frames her decision-making as the head of the third largest school district in the country.

episodes.title: A Classic Problem -- Putting Diverse Books into Practice
episodes.description: The books children read in the classroom today look a lot like they did decades ago. Kim Parker, cofounder of #Disrupttexts, wants to change that. In this EdCast, she addresses the challenges facing educators trying to diversify books in their classroom. With diverse books regularly appearing on the American Library Association's most challenged and banned books in libraries and schools, Parker discusses this and our inability to move beyond the literary canon. She offers ideas for educators trying to take steps to incorporate diverse books in their practice and how parents can be supportive allies in the process.

episodes.title: Understanding Immigration
episodes.description: Regardless of how you might feel about immigration, Harvard Professor Roberto Gonzales thinks we need to better understand its implications and how it affects everyday life of immigrants and beyond. In this episode, Gonzales discusses the immigration crisis in America and his new effort, the Immigration Initiative at Harvard, to connect researchers, policymakers, and immigrant communities together in dialogue, supportive action, and shared learning.

episodes.title: The Quest for Deeper Learning in High Schools
episodes.description: Harvard researchers Jal Mehta and Sarah Fine talk about what they discovered while studying nontraditional, innovative high schools, and what we can learn from the pockets of great work happening around the country.

episodes.title: EdCast Extra: Teens Get Real About Inequity in College Access
episodes.description: In this EdCast extra, Harvard Senior Lecturer Richard Weissbourd along with Nicolas Burgess, 17, and Dequan Franks, 19, from Jacksonville, Florida, speak about the EVAC movement, experiences as "at-risk" youth, and address the immense inequities facing some students.

episodes.title: Putting Ethics First in College Admissions
episodes.description: Harvard Psychologist Rick Weissbourd guides parents (and high schools) to be better ethical role models, especially in the college admissions process.

episodes.title: The Making of a Bully-free School
episodes.description: Educator Tina Owen-Moore speaks about the creation of the Alliance School in Milwaukee and strategies to combat bullying.

episodes.title: Redefining School Counseling
episodes.description: Mandy Savitz Romer, senior lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, shares misconceptions about the profession, and how the school counselor role should change to better support children.

episodes.title: Broadening Global Perspectives
episodes.description: Peace Corps Director Jody Olsen discusses the world of global education, and how educators can incorporate a global approach in the classroom.

episodes.title: The Desegregation Compromise
episodes.description: Vanessa Siddle Walker, professor of African American educational studies at Emory College, discusses the role of black educators in desegregation efforts and why school integration didn't end up working as hoped.

episodes.title: Moving Beyond Technical in Computer Science Education
episodes.description: Sepehr Vakil, an assistant professor at Northwestern University, talks about the importance of looking at computer science education beyond just the technical – and what a more ethical and power balanced computer science course might look like in education.

episodes.title: The Complexities of Teacher Strikes
episodes.description: Harvard Professor Marty West talks about the wave of teacher strikes happening throughout the country and the complexities of teacher compensation that make it difficult to raise salaries.

episodes.title: Overparented, Underprepared
episodes.description: Julie Lythcott-Haims, the former dean of freshmen at Stanford University, talks about the dangers of overparenting and how it can make or break a child's success at college.

episodes.title: The Rights of Public School Students
episodes.description: Justin Driver, a professor of law at the University of Chicago Law School, reflects on the history of Supreme Court education rulings and foreshadows legal issues that may be percolating in public schools today.

episodes.title: Replicating Effective Charter School Practice
episodes.description: Sarah Cohodes, an assistant professor at Teachers College, talks about the state of charter schools and whether we can transfer effective charter school practice to traditional public schools.

episodes.title: How Colleges Fail Disadvantaged Students
episodes.description: Tony Jack, author of The Privileged Poor and assistant professor at Harvard, discusses the experiences of low income students as colleges try to diversify student population, and ways we can change it for the better.

episodes.title: Reducing Absences, Capturing School Days
episodes.description: Todd Rogers, a professor at the Harvard Kennedy School and also director of the Student Social Support R&D lab, talks about discovering an effective intervention against chronic absenteeism, how to get more students back in class, and what seems to work in targeting absent students.

episodes.title: From Prison to Ph.D.
episodes.description: Dr. Stanley Andrisse, director of From Prison Cell to Ph.D., shares his story and discusses the school to prison pipeline, and how higher education can remove barriers for formerly incarcerated people so they can use education to transform their lives.

episodes.title: A Promise for Education
episodes.description: Oakland Mayor Libby Schaaf shares why she has focused so much of her term on education, and particularly the creation of Oakland Promise, which aims to get more kids to acquire postsecondary education.

episodes.title: How Personalized Learning Can Lead to Success
episodes.description: Lecturer Todd Rose discusses the importance of personalized learning in the quest for success, and how success will look different in the future.

episodes.title: Reaching Rural South Africa through Education
episodes.description: Craig Paxton, executive director of Axium Education, shares the work being done to reach the millions of children living in rural communities throughout South Africa and the importance of providing education for this population.

episodes.title: The State of Sex Ed in America
episodes.description: Catherine Brown, vice president of education policy at the Center for American Progress, provides insight into sex education standards around the country and the shift to do more.

episodes.title: The Harvard Trial: Evaluating Fairness in College Admissions
episodes.description: Natasha Warikoo, an associate professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, discusses the Harvard trial and whether college admissions can ever truly be fair.

episodes.title: Finding Faith in Education
episodes.description: Irvin Scott, a senior lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, talks about why faith leaders can be key players in educational outcomes for children.

episodes.title: Lessons Learned from the 2015 Mizzou Protests
episodes.description: Ben Trachtenberg, an associate professor of law at the University of Missouri, gives an insider look at what happened during the 2015 Mizzou protests that led to resignations, decreased enrollment rates, and budget cuts.

episodes.title: The Transformative Power of Arts Education
episodes.description: Andria Zafirakou, the 2018 Global Teacher Prize winner, shares how the arts can be a powerful tool of inclusion and resilience for children.

episodes.title: Who Goes to Private School?
episodes.description: Stanford Professor Sean Reardon talks about the downward trend in private school enrollments, what this tells us about the middle class in America, and why it’s important for everyone to pay attention to who goes to private school.

episodes.title: Demoralized, Not Drained
episodes.description: Doris Santoro, an associate professor at Bowdoin, explores how many teachers are demoralized not burnt out in the profession. She also discusses how school leaders can stave off this phenomenon and gives sound advice for teachers.

episodes.title: Friday Night Lights Out: A Call to End Football in Schools
episodes.description: Randall Curren, a professor at the University of Rochester, discusses why it’s ethically indefensible for schools to continue sponsoring tackle football.

episodes.title: Putting Mister Rogers' Deep and Simple to Practice
episodes.description: Early childhood education expert Junlei Li spoke to the Harvard EdCast recently about the meaning of high quality in early childhood education, how Fred Rogers' legacy influenced his work, and what deep and simple actually looks like in practice.

episodes.title: Questioning the Truth in History
episodes.description: Activist Minnijean Brown-Trickey discusses the Little Rock Nine and the importance of uncovering and understanding the truth in America.

episodes.title: Kids Need a Break
episodes.description: Stanford University's Denise Pope, also co-founder of Challenge Success, shares what we need to think about when it comes to choosing summer enrichment programs for our children, and offers some alternatives to children's rigid academic programs in the summer.

episodes.title: Smartphones, Teens, and Unhappiness
episodes.description: San Diego State University Professor Jean Twenge talks about her research that examining teens, smartphones and unhappiness.

episodes.title: Escuela Nueva
episodes.description: Vicki Colbert, Yidan Prize winner, reflects on her work and research with Escuela Nueva.

episodes.title: Learning for Careers
episodes.description: Bob Schwartz and Nancy Hoffman, co-founders of the Pathways to Prosperity network and HGSE faculty, discuss what they’ve learned about preparing students for the workplace.

episodes.title: The Surprising Cost of School Security
episodes.description: UC-Berkeley Professor Calvin Morrill talks about how a high school changed with increased security policies, and shares some perspective on how this might inform the current debate about school security.

episodes.title: Tackling Issues in Education
episodes.description: CJ Anderson, Super Bowl champion for the Denver Broncos, reflects on his community activism work and shares tips for other non-profit leaders.

episodes.title: Angel Investments
episodes.description: Angel Rich, founder and CEO of The Wealth Factory, examines the intersection of financial literacy, technology, and education.

episodes.title: Making Smart Choices in Today's Screen-filled World
episodes.description: Children's television producer Angela Santomero shares the inspirations behind her hit shows like Daniel Tiger's Neighborhood, and talks about how parents can use television in smart and healthy ways.

episodes.title: AI and Education
episodes.description: Stephen Wolfram, CEO of Wolfram Research, reflects on the evolving role of computational literacy and AI in education.

episodes.title: Mindset and Parenting
episodes.description: Carol Dweck, Stanford professor of psychology, examines mindset, motivation, and parenting tips in the context of recently receiving the Yidan Prize.

episodes.title: Committing to the #CommonGood
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd, faculty director of Making Caring Common, discusses the launch of the Caring Schools #CommonGood Campaign.

episodes.title: Ask More of Him
episodes.description: Jackson Katz, an educator, activist, and creator of the Mentors in Violence Prevention program, discusses the significant role men play in preventing gender violence and creating more gender equality in light of movements like Metoo.

episodes.title: Is "Free College" Really Free?
episodes.description: Is "Free College" Really Free? by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: Dr. Ruth Talks Sex and Ed
episodes.description: Dr. Ruth Talks Sex and Ed by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: Walking the Talk - Episode 2 - John Wilson
episodes.description: John Wilson, former president of Morehouse College and former executive director of the White House Initiative on Historically Black Colleges and Universities, talks to Domonic Rollins about educating black boys, obstacles on the road to college, and other issues affecting student equity.

episodes.title: Elmo Goes To Harvard
episodes.description: Elmo (along with executive vice president Sherrie Westin) from Sesame Street visit the Harvard Ed School campus to discuss the global work Sesame Workshop is doing to educate young children displaced by conflict and persecution.

episodes.title: Childhood adversity's Lasting Effect
episodes.description: Pediatrician Nadine Burke Harris shares how childhood adversity creates toxic stress that can impact health long term, and particularly how intervention and response through collaborative efforts can significantly alter children's futures.

episodes.title: Cornel West: Love, Hope, and Education
episodes.description: Cornel West: Love, Hope, and Education by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: The Troublemakers at School
episodes.description: Researcher and Author Carla Shalaby shares what she discovered from following four "troublemakers" as they made their way at school.

episodes.title: Developing Critical Thinking Skills
episodes.description: Georgetown University Professor William T. Gormley, Jr., discusses the importance of teaching critical thinking skills, especially in these times of “fake news.”

episodes.title: What “the Talk” Black Parents Have with Their Sons Tells Us About Racism
episodes.description: Columbia University Assistant Professor Raygine DiAquoi shares what she discovered about how black parents talk to their sons today about race and discrimination.

episodes.title: Lifelong Kindergarten
episodes.description: MIT Professor Mitch Resnick, author of “Lifelong Kindergarten: Cultivating Creativity through Projects, Passion, Peers, and Play”, talks about creativity in learning and explains why kindergarten is the greatest invention of the last millennium.

episodes.title: Urban Preparation
episodes.description: Chezare A. Warren, Assistant Professor at Michigan State University, reflects on urban teacher preparation, culturally responsive teaching, and critical race theory in education.

episodes.title: A Culture of Anxiety? The Culture is Us
episodes.description: Psychotherapist Lynn Lyons talks about her work training educators to respond to student anxiety, and provides insight on what schools get right or wrong about anxiety in children.

episodes.title: The Importance of Refugee Education
episodes.description: John Palmer, Associate Professor and Chair of Educational Studies at Colgate University, reflects on refugee education in the Korean peninsula and beyond.

episodes.title: Blurred Lines: Rethinking Sex, Power, and Consent on Campus
episodes.description: Vanessa Grigoriadis, author, explores what’s really happening behind closed doors on America’s college campuses.

episodes.title: Advocating for Girl Education Around the World
episodes.description: Documentary filmmaker and girls' education advocate Zuriel Oduwole discusses what inspired her to become an advocate for better access to girls' education across the world.

episodes.title: Understanding the NCAA
episodes.description: Mark Emmert, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) reflects on the evolving role of college athletics, amateurism in college sports, and his favorite moment as a fan.

episodes.title: Faith Ed.
episodes.description: Journalist Linda Wertheimer, author of Faith Ed: Teaching about Religion in an Age of Intolerance, looks at the challenges faced by public schools when incorporating lessons about world religions into their classrooms.

episodes.title: An American in China's Schools
episodes.description: Chinese-American journalist Lenora Chu arrived in Shanghai in 2010 with her family enrolling her son in a top-performing school. Chu discusses the culture clash she experienced in her book, “Little Soldiers: An American Boy, Chinese School, and the Global Race to Achieve," and what America could learn from China.

episodes.title: You Cannot Be What You Cannot See
episodes.description: Reshma Saujani, Founder and CEO of Girls Who Code, reflects on her organization's mission and why it is so crucial and important to the world.

episodes.title: The Intersection of Education and Incarceration
episodes.description: Erin Castro, assistant professor at the University of Utah, reflects on co-publishing in the Harvard Ed Review with an incarcerated student of hers.

episodes.title: Supporting Transgender Students at School
episodes.description: Jeff Perrotti, founding director of the Safe Schools Program for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer and Questioning, discusses issues facing transgender students and how schools can provide support.

episodes.title: Addicted to Reform
episodes.description: John Merrow, former education correspondent for the PBS NewsHour, shares insights from his new book "Addicted to Reform: A 12-Step Program to Rescue Public Education."

episodes.title: Separating Good Change from Bad
episodes.description: Helen Janc Malone, Ed.D.’13, and Santiago Rincón-Gallardo, Ed.M.’07, Ed.D.’13, discuss trends reshaping the field of education and their new book, Future Directions of Educational Change: Social Justice, Professional Capital, and Systems Change.

episodes.title: Learning for the Test Prep
episodes.description: Mike Palmer and Esther Lee, Ed.M.’14 discuss designing digital learning and their pedagogical approach at Kaplan.

episodes.title: The Mythbuster
episodes.description: Christopher Cerf, Superintendent of Newark Public Schools, reflects on his work and the history of Newark Public Schools.

episodes.title: The Talk
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd, HGSE faculty, discusses a new report looking at how young people struggle with romantic relationships and deal with widespread misogyny and harassment.

episodes.title: Girl Power: Raising Female Activists
episodes.description: Colby College Professor Lyn Mikel Brown talks about how to empower young female activists.

episodes.title: Green Mountain Education
episodes.description: Rebecca Holcombe, secretary of education for the state of Vermont, talks priorities and progress in leading the state's unique education system.

episodes.title: Teaching Tolerance Today
episodes.description: Maureen Costello, director of the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Teaching Tolerance project, reflects on the historical and current importance of providing anti-bias education resources — and how they can better society.

episodes.title: Schools that Succeed
episodes.description: Author Karin Chenoweth talks about her latest book, "Schools that Succeed," and how educators can break down the link between academic achievement and socioeconomic status.

episodes.title: How to Create Good Men
episodes.description: Colby College Professor Mark Tappan discusses how to create good men and the problems with toxic masculinity.

episodes.title: Chang(e) Agent
episodes.description: Tommy Chang, superintendent of Boston Public Schools, reflects on his leadership, vision, and why he chose education as a career.

episodes.title: A Life Animated by Autism
episodes.description: Pulitzer-prize winning writer Ron Suskind discusses being a father to his Autistic son, and how it inspired the book and film, "A Life Animated," and his autism activist work.

episodes.title: Creator of Sit With Us App Pushes Back at Bullying
episodes.description: Sixteen-year-old Natalie Hampton shares her experience with bullying and how it prompted her to create the app "Sit With Us."

episodes.title: Teaching in Complex Times
episodes.description: A moderated conversation with HGSE scholars on how educators can navigate ethical dilemmas in the classroom — and protect students from bullying, confront divisions, and foster inclusion.

episodes.title: Keeping the DREAM alive for undocumented students in college
episodes.description: University of Central Arkansas Assistant Professor Jesus Cisneros, also cofounder of DREAMZone, discusses the unique challenges facing undocumented students and higher education, and how to keep the dream alive.

episodes.title: A Champion for Public Education
episodes.description: Former Virginia Secretary of Education Anne Holton discusses how to be a champion for public education, women as leaders, and her new role as an education board member.

episodes.title: Walking Around the World
episodes.description: Pulitzer-Prize winning Journalist Paul Salopek discusses the Out of Eden Walk -- a 21,000-mile journey where he retraces the migratory pathways of our human ancestors.

episodes.title: A Tweet that Pays for School Lunch
episodes.description: Ashley Ford, writer and blogger, discusses how her Tweet about paying off school lunch debt inspired people to raise $150,000.

episodes.title: A Conversation with Rev. Jesse Jackson
episodes.description: Rev. Jesse Jackson, activist and minister, reflects on the current political climate and shares his thoughts on the role of education as a means of fighting inequality.

episodes.title: Supporting the New Majority Student
episodes.description: Sr. Kathleen Ross, president emerita at Heritage University, identifies effective strategies that faculty have used to help New Majority students build the necessary skills to succeed in college.

episodes.title: The Sandy Hook Promise
episodes.description: Nicole Hockley, founder and managing director of Sandy Hook Promise, shares thoughts on how to prevent gun-related deaths so that no other parent experiences the senseless, horrific loss of their child.

episodes.title: From China to Harvard
episodes.description: Dejian Liu, founder of NetDragon Websoft Holding, discusses the intersection of tech and education -- and how that brought him to Harvard.

episodes.title: The Mythology of the Millennial
episodes.description: Sam Wineburg, Professor at the Stanford Graduate School of Education, examines how youth determine whether information is real or fake on the Internet — and what can be done to help them make those decisions.

episodes.title: Hiring a Diverse Faculty
episodes.description: Marybeth Gasman, Professor of Education at the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education, reflects on the challenges in hiring a diverse faculty at the college and university level.

episodes.title: Changemaking
episodes.description: Ross Hall, Director for Education, Ashoka Europe, discusses his unique work on improving the world.

episodes.title: Guiding Children in Uncertain Times
episodes.description: Guiding Children in Uncertain Times by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: The Diversity Bargain
episodes.description: Natasha K. Warikoo, associate professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, reflects on the notions of race, merit, and privilege in elite universities.

episodes.title: Uncommon App
episodes.description: Christopher Gray, founder and CEO of Scholly, explains the mission and impact of his college scholarhsip app.

episodes.title: Educating Military Children
episodes.description: Dr. Jill Biden, Second Lady of the United States, discusses the educational experiences of the over 2 million military- and veteran-connected students in our K-12 classrooms.

episodes.title: Immigration Reform and Education
episodes.description: Angela Maria Kelley, executive director, Center for American Progress Action Fund, reflects on the first 15 years of the DREAM Act, legislation to provide undocumented immigrants who arrived in the United States as children a path toward legal status through education or the military.

episodes.title: One In A Billion
episodes.description: Mable Chan, president and founder of China Personified, discusses “One In A Billion” a podcast about China, through the voices of Chinese millennials in America.

episodes.title: I Wish My Teacher Knew
episodes.description: Kyle Schwartz, third-grade teacher and author, explains how one question can change everything for our kids.

episodes.title: Why You Should Dance in the Rain
episodes.description: Jerome T. Murphy, scholar and former dean of HGSE, shares his perspective on helping education leaders thrive under pressure by developing the inner strengths of mindfulness and self-compassion, expressing emotions wisely, and maintaining a clear focus on the values that matter most.

episodes.title: Global Teacher of the Year
episodes.description: Hanan Al Hroub, winner of the 2016 Global Teacher Prize, speaks about her experiences as a Palestinian educator and her unique approach to instruction.

episodes.title: The Case For Homework
episodes.description: Harris M. Cooper, professor at Duke University, explains the reasons why all children should be doing homework.

episodes.title: Online Reading In Schools
episodes.description: Donald Leu, professor of education at the University of Connecticut Neag School of Education, explores how today’s educator must envision new ways of reading online.

episodes.title: What Is Equity in Education?
episodes.description: Robert Smith, co-author of the book "Striving for Equity" examines making progress toward narrowing opportunity and achievement gaps in traditional school districts with diverse populations and multiple, competing agendas.

episodes.title: What Happens After Yes
episodes.description: Peggy Orenstein, author of the book "Girls and Sex" examines how teens can better navigate from shame and regret to integrity and wellness when it comes to sex.

episodes.title: Higher Education in China
episodes.description: Judy Lam, Chancellor and Board Director at Wuhan College, reflects on the state of public and private higher education in China.

episodes.title: Portrait of an Educator
episodes.description: Sonia Nieto, educator and author of the book "Brooklyn Dreams: My Life in Public Education," looks back on her formative experiences as a student, activist, and educator, and shows how they reflect and illuminate the themes of her life’s work in multicultural education.

episodes.title: The World Course
episodes.description: Fernando Reimers, professor at HGSE, shares a curriculum that is designed to empower global citizens around the world.

episodes.title: Leading Disruptive Change in Education
episodes.description: Rick Hess, co-editor of the book 'Educational Entrepreneurship Today,' reflects on what it takes to be a successful entrepreneur in education.

episodes.title: Debugging the Gender Gap
episodes.description: Robin Hauser Reynolds, director of the film "Code: Debugging the Gender Gap" discusses both the message and movement associated with having more women and minorities code.

episodes.title: Winning Marriage Equality
episodes.description: Julie Goodridge, lead plaintiff in the landmark Massachusetts case Goodridge v. Dept. of Public Health, reflects on her life's journey and discussed her time at HGSE.

episodes.title: Understanding Educational Ethics
episodes.description: Meira Levinson, co-editor of the book, Dilemmas of Educational Ethics, shares challenging questions of ethics, justice, and equity that educators and policy makers confront on a regular basis.

episodes.title: The Role of Family In A Child's Success
episodes.description: John R. Connolly, Co-Founder and Executive Director at 1647, reflects on how to design and implement family engagement strategies that support student learning and success in school.

episodes.title: How To Give Good Feedback
episodes.description: Ellie Drago-Severson, professor at Teachers College, reflects on the value of constructive feedback, examining her new co-authored book, "Tell Me So I Can Hear You."

episodes.title: Helping Children Succeed
episodes.description: Paul Tough, NYTimes best selling author, examines how to make kids more motivated, engaged, and productive in the classroom.

episodes.title: Facebook Education
episodes.description: Adam Seldow, Head of Education Partnerships at Facebook, reflects on the landscape of personalized learning and discusses why Facebook is partnering with Summit Public Schools.

episodes.title: Books, Movies, and Civic Engagement
episodes.description: Harvard professors Bob Selman and Joe Blatt reflect on 21st century learning through transmedia storytelling.

episodes.title: How To Become a School Principal
episodes.description: Sarah Fiarman, Lecturer at HGSE, discusses her new book "Becoming a School Principal: Learning to Lead, Leading to Learn."

episodes.title: Educating Girls Globally
episodes.description: Irina Bokova, Director-General of UNESCO, reflects on the global constraints that girls and women face to receiving an education and what UNESCO is doing to help.

episodes.title: Finding Passion in Learning
episodes.description: Steve Seidel, member of the HGSE faculty, discusses passion driven learning with Cristina Pato, member of the Silk Road Ensemble.

episodes.title: A New Way of Being at Work
episodes.description: Lisa Lahey, HGSE faculty and author of the book "An Everyone Culture" discusses a radical new model for unleashing your company’s (or schools’s) potential.

episodes.title: World Religions for the World Wide Web
episodes.description: Diane Moore, Senior Lecturer and the Director of the Religious Literacy Project at Harvard University, examines both the mechanics and importance of teaching religion to a global community.

episodes.title: The Common(wealth) Core
episodes.description: Lindsay Sobel, Massachusetts Senior Executive Director of Teach Plus, reflects on the pulse of the common core state standards in MA schools.

episodes.title: The New American Mosaic
episodes.description: Alejandra Y. Castillo, national director of the Minority Business Development Agency at the U.S. Department of Commerce, examines whether or not the United States will continue to be globally competitive in an ever-changing economic and technological landscape.

episodes.title: The Professional Kindergartener
episodes.description: Sandra Boynton, children's book author and illustrator, reflects on her eclectic career in the arts and examines the role of joy in her work.

episodes.title: The History of History
episodes.description: Larry Cuban, professor emeritus of education at Stanford University, reflects on the stability and change of teaching history in American schools.

episodes.title: A Global Search for Inclusive Practices
episodes.description: Rodrigo Mendes, founder of an institute dedicated to inclusive education, reflects on his global quest for improving social change amongst people with disabilities.

episodes.title: Cynics With Good Reason
episodes.description:
Robert Putnam, Harvard Kennedy School professor and author of "Our Kids: The American Dream in Crisis”
reflects on what educators can do to help restore some measure of social mobility in our society.

episodes.title: Can States Take Over & Turn Around School Districts?
episodes.description: David Deming, associate professor at HGSE, and Beth Schueler, doctoral student at HGSE, reflect on lessons learned from the state's successful school takeover in Lawrence, MA.

episodes.title: Next Level Entrepreneurship
episodes.description: Monica Higgins, professor at HGSE, shares news of an upcoming opportunity that aims to provide strategies that enhance and expand what works in education.

episodes.title: Notes from Ferguson's Superintendent
episodes.description: Joseph Davis, superintendent of the Ferguson-Florissant School District, examines the foundational role of schools in a community under the national spotlight.

episodes.title: Leadership Lessons from the University of Virginia President
episodes.description: Teresa Sullivan, President of the University of Virginia, reflects on leadership, her role models, and tips for developing a strong culture in higher education.

episodes.title: Community EdReform
episodes.description: Kaya Henderson, Chancellor, DC Public Schools, reflects on the complexity of education reform and examines successes and challenges during her time as chancellor.

episodes.title: What's Replacing 'No Child Left Behind?'
episodes.description: Marty West, associate professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, discusses the big changes in federal legislation replacing "No Child Left Behind."

episodes.title: The Evolution of Disabilities Education
episodes.description: Tom Hehir, professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, reflects on the state of disabilities education as we celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA).

episodes.title: #LongLiveTheQueen
episodes.description: Landon Patterson, the first transgender Homecoming Queen at her school in Missouri, reflects on her story of courage and love.

episodes.title: Rac(e)ing to Class
episodes.description: H. Richard Milner IV, author and professor at the University of Pittsburgh School for Education, examines ways in which we can confront poverty and race in schools and classrooms.

episodes.title: Examining Blended Learning
episodes.description: Sari Factor, CEO of Edgenuity, examines the value of blended learning in the schoolwide ecosystem.

episodes.title: When Does Accountability Work?
episodes.description: David Deming, associate professor at HGSE, examines test based accountability as it relates to college graduation rates and future earnings.

episodes.title: How We're Failing Our Brightest Kids
episodes.description: Chester Finn, author of the book "Failing Our Brightest Kids” discusses the global challenge of educating high-ability students.

episodes.title: Inside the Mind of a Teacher
episodes.description: Vanessa Rodriguez, advanced doctoral student and author of the book, "The Teaching Brain,” examines the intersection of education, neuroscience, and everyday experience

episodes.title: Reading and the Common Core
episodes.description: P. David Pearson, Professor, Graduate School of Education, University of California - Berkeley, examines the theory and practice in reading comprehension.

episodes.title: Overcoming the Stresses of Education Leadership
episodes.description: Rick Hanson, author and psychologist, reflects on how educators can build inner strengths and be more mindful leaders.

episodes.title: The Fallout of Education Reform in Newark
episodes.description: Dale Russakoff, author of "The Prize," examines the troubled education reform story of Newark and reflects on what can be learned from its failure to provide system wide reform.

episodes.title: The Future Of Learning Spaces
episodes.description: Stephen Ervin and Kristin Sullivan, Learning Spaces Week Co-Chairs, reflect on the future of learning spaces in education.

episodes.title: Colleges and Businesses
episodes.description: Peter Stokes, author of the book "Higher Education and Employability" examines new models for integrating study and work in the context of 21st century learning.

episodes.title: Defining American in the Classroom
episodes.description: Karen Willemsen, education director for Define American, reflects on how educators can help undocumented high school students graduate informed, empowered, and thinking about furthering their education.

episodes.title: Student-Centered Learning
episodes.description: Bill Nave, author and research consultant, explains how and why teaching can be redesigned for classrooms in order to “reach every child.”

episodes.title: From HGSE to the White House
episodes.description: Roberto Rodriguez, deputy assistant to President Obama for education, examines the intersection of public policy and education, and reflects on a career that brought him from HGSE to the White House.

episodes.title: Learning to Love or Hate
episodes.description: Farah Pandith, Adjunct Senior Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, reflects on inclusion and exclusion through the lens of religious differences.

episodes.title: Learning Without Liberty?
episodes.description: Cevin Soling, author of "The Student Resistance Handbook," shares his controversial opinions on the role of schools in the education of American youth.

episodes.title: States and Schools
episodes.description: Chris Minnich, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO), reflects on the challenges facing states in the increasingly politicized field of education.

episodes.title: Healthy Identity Development
episodes.description: Jennifer Bryan, psychologist and author, discusses gender and heteronormativity with HGSE's Rick Weissbourd.

episodes.title: Is Public Education Dead?
episodes.description: David Kirp, author and professor, argues that there is a way to rebuild the public education system and close the achievement gap for all students.

episodes.title: Summer Code
episodes.description: Karen Brennan, assistant professor at HGSE, shares tips for engaging students in summer coding.

episodes.title: A First Choice Profession
episodes.description: Randi Weingarten, president of the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), shares her thoughts on how to improve the teaching profession and why we need more excellent teachers in this country.

episodes.title: Roots of the School Gardening Movement
episodes.description: Jane Hirschi, author of the book 'Ripe for Change: Garden-Based Learning in Schools,' reflects on garden-based learning in public K–8 education.

episodes.title: The Power of Listening
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd and Eve Ewing, researchers at HGSE, examine how to speak with youth about turmoil, strife, and community challenges--with a particular focus on what has been happening recently in Baltimore.

episodes.title: Why I Love Baltimore
episodes.description: Andres Alonso, HGSE professor and former CEO of Baltimore City Public Schools, reflects on the recent protests in Baltimore and examines their impact on schools and children in a broader national context.

episodes.title: The Wisdom of Data
episodes.description: Kathy Boudett, director of the Data Wise Project, shares details of her new edX course called "Introduction to Data Wise: A Collaborative Process to Improve Learning & Teaching."

episodes.title: Write the World
episodes.description: David Weinstein, founder and CEO of Write the World, shares his vision for helping students develop the writing strategies and communication tools essential for success in school, career, and life.

episodes.title: Latin America Learns: Building Participation & Civic Engagement for the 21st Century
episodes.description: Alicia Lebrija, president of Fundación Televisa, reflects on why she is passionate about education and shares her hopes for the upcoming Latin America Education Conference at HGSE.

episodes.title: Examining the Atlanta Teachers Cheating Scandal
episodes.description: Daniel Koretz, professor of education at HGSE, reflects on the Atlanta cheating scandal and its impact on policy.

episodes.title: A Brief History of Standarized Testing
episodes.description: Anya Kamenetz, NPR's lead education blogger, sits down to discuss high-stakes testing in American schools and the effects they are having on children, teachers, and society.

episodes.title: Part 1 March 23 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About The Practicum.WMA
episodes.description: Part 1 March 23 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About The Practicum.WMA by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: March 25 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About Race And Equity.WMA
episodes.description: March 25 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About Race And Equity.WMA by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: Part 2 March 23 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About The Practicum.WMA
episodes.description: Part 2 March 23 2015 Admitted Student Conf Call About The Practicum.WMA by Harvard Graduate School of Education

episodes.title: Navigating Disability
episodes.description: Anne Marcus, cofounder of Excptional Lives, and Chris Spence, educational developer, reflect on ways of improving disability awareness on 2015 World Autism Awareness Day.

episodes.title: Presidents, Congress, and the Public Schools
episodes.description: Jack Jennings, founder and former CEO of the Center on Education Policy, reflects on the history of the federal government's involvement with education reform.

episodes.title: Schools Of New York
episodes.description: Carmen Fariña, Chancellor of the NYC Department of Education, shares her vision and goals for leading the nation’s largest school district.

episodes.title: How Do You Define American?
episodes.description: Jose Antonio Vargas, Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, shares his story of what it means to be American.

episodes.title: From Newark to the Ivy League
episodes.description: Jeff Hobbs, author of 'The Short and Tragic Life of Robert Peace' reflects on the lessons from his new book.

episodes.title: Astronaut School
episodes.description: Stephanie Wilson, NASA astronaut, speaks with 9-year old guest co-host Grace Laplante about the importance of female role models in STEM careers, her adventures in space, and shares lesser known facts about astronaut ice cream.

episodes.title: Reimagining Affirmative Action
episodes.description: Sheryll Cashin, professor of law at Georgetown University explains how the social costs of racial preferences actually outweigh any of the marginal benefits when effective race-neutral alternatives are available.

episodes.title: Education and Corruption
episodes.description: Stephen Heyneman, professor at Vanderbilt University reflects on the role of corruption in educational settings around the world.

episodes.title: The Global Classroom
episodes.description: Fernando Reimers, professor at HGSE, reflects on the increasingly important role global education plays in schools around the world.

episodes.title: Into the (Piney) Woods
episodes.description: Will Crossley, president of the Piney Woods School, reflects on education leadership, being the first alumnus to lead the school in its 105-year history, and whether he enjoys eating chicken nuggets with students.

episodes.title: Andres Alonso Discusses the Leadership Institute for Superintendents and District Leaders
episodes.description: Andres Alonso discusses the upcoming institute 'Leadership Institute for Superintendents and District Leaders.'

episodes.title: How To Be Super
episodes.description: Andres Alonso, former CEO of Baltimore Public Schools and current HGSE professor, provides an insightful perspective on the complex role of the school superintendent.

episodes.title: The Power of Convening
episodes.description: Jacqueline Jones, president of the Foundation for Child Development, reflects on the dialogue and unique collaborations between researchers and practioners in the field of early childhood education.

episodes.title: Tips For Turnaround
episodes.description: Jeff Riley, superintendent/receiver of Lawrence Public Schools, shares his playbook for leading a successful school district turnaround.

episodes.title: Pursuing Brilliance Across the Pond
episodes.description: Simon Coyle, founder of The Brilliant Club, shares his international plan to widen access to top universities for outstanding pupils from non-selective state schools.

episodes.title: Streamlining Early Learning
episodes.description: Bobbie Burnham, early childhood educator, shares successes and strategies from her time working in the Minnesota Dept. of Education.

episodes.title: Becoming a Soul Rebel
episodes.description: Shawn Ginwright, author and activist, responds to the crisis of hopelessness among youth of color in urban America.

episodes.title: F = Ma(ster Class)
episodes.description: Eric Mazur, professor of physics at Harvard, discusses his upcoming Master Class titled 'Confessions of a Converted Lecturer.'

episodes.title: How Stereotypes Affect Us
episodes.description: Claude Steele, author of the book 'Whistling Vivaldi,' explains his research on stereotype threat and provides solutions for mitigating its negative effects.

episodes.title: Social Justice Art
episodes.description: Marit Dewhurst, director of art education at The City College of New York, explains the power of using art as a way to engage students in addressing issues of social injustice.

episodes.title: The Importance of Years 0-5
episodes.description: Nonie Lesaux and Stephanie Jones, members of the faculty at HGSE, examine the latest thinking, research, and practice in building and sustaining high quality Pre-K systems, schools and classrooms.

episodes.title: Potato Chips or Research Spending? Examining Human Infrastructure in Higher Education
episodes.description: Mark Yudof, former president of the University of California, reflects on the changing nature of higher education in America and looks to the future of the post-secondary education experience.

episodes.title: Education and Ferguson, MO
episodes.description: Richard Rothestein, visiting scholar in education at HGSE, shares insights into how education has been affected by racial-isolation policies that primed Ferguson for this summer’s events.

episodes.title: Examining the 'M' in MOOC
episodes.description: Justin Reich, adjunct lecturer on education at HGSE, reflects on the design process of his new course, 'Massive: The Future of Learning at Scale.'

episodes.title: Inner Strength Leadership Training
episodes.description: Jerry Murphy and Metta McGarvey, faculty for the upcoming PPE institute, 'Inner Strengths of Successful Leaders,' share insight into the growing practice of mindful leadership.

episodes.title: How Caring is Your School?
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd, co-director of the Making Caring Common Project, outlines a new way for schools to examine their culture and environment through the power of big data.

episodes.title: The Finnish Education Ambassador
episodes.description: Pasi Sahlberg, author of the book 'Finnish Lessons' reflects on what the world can learn from educational change in Finland. #ICYMI

episodes.title: Are We Privatizing Public Universities?
episodes.description: Matthew Lambert, author of the book 'Privatization and the Public Good' reflects on the momentous challenges plaguing present day public universities.

episodes.title: Planting the Seeds of STEM Careers
episodes.description: Catherine Riegle-Crumb, associate professor at UT Austin, shares insight into the gender divide in schools and how this relates to gender disparities in STEM careers.

episodes.title: Admissions Merit in the U.S. and Abroad
episodes.description: Natasha Warikoo, associate professor at HGSE, analyzes how students in elite institutions understand merit in admissions, looking at schools both in England and the United States.

episodes.title: Want To Run a Better Meeting?
episodes.description: Kathy Boudett and Liz City, co-authors of the book 'Meeting Wise,' reflect on how meeting planning can become a key strategy in the service of school improvement.

episodes.title: The Future of Independent Schools
episodes.description: John Chubb, president of the National Association of Independent Schools (NAIS), reflects on the future of independent schools and examines how school administrators can lead in a changing context.

episodes.title: Protecting Your Child's Brain
episodes.description: Professor Jack Shonkoff, director of the Center on the Developing Child at Harvard University, explains some of the science behind early childhood development and how education can help.

episodes.title: On Being a First: The College Presidency
episodes.description:
New college presidents reflect on being a first.

Order of speaking:
Alicia Harvey Smith, River Valley Community College, Claremont, NH

Elizabeth Davis, President of Furman University in South Carolina,
 
Laurie Leshin, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, Worcester, MA
 
Joanne Berger-Sweeney, Trinity College, Hartford, CT

episodes.title: Four Female College Presidents Reflect
episodes.description:
Participants in the "Harvard Seminar for New Presidents" reflect on the program and being part of a diverse cohort.

Order of talking:

Elizabeth Davis, President of Furman University in South Carolina,
Laurie Leshin, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, Worcester, MA
Joanne Berger-Sweeney, Trinity College, Hartford, CT
Alicia Harvey Smith, River Valley Community College, Claremont, NH

episodes.title: A Conversation w/Ted Mitchell: Improving College Counseling
episodes.description: Ted Mitchell, Under Secretary of the U.S. Department of Education, reflects on the great importance of equity in education and the national movement to expand college readiness, college access, and college completion.

episodes.title: A Conversation w/Eric Waldo: Reaching Higher
episodes.description: Eric Waldo, executive director of First Lady Michelle Obama’s Reach Higher Initiative, reflects on the origins and goals of the HGSE/White House co-sponsored event, "College Opportunity Agenda: Strengthening School Counseling and College Advising."

episodes.title: East Meets West In the Classroom
episodes.description: Jin Li, professor of education at Brown University, examines the differences between western and eastern learners.

episodes.title: The Children We Mean To Raise
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd, senior lecturer at HGSE, shares findings from his new 'Making Caring Common' project report examining the real messages adults are sending about values.

episodes.title: To Disagree, But Not Be Disagreeable
episodes.description: Mike Johnston, Colorado state senator, reflects on his commencement speech (and protests), his vision for American education, and best practices for thoughtfully communicating in broader education discourse.

episodes.title: Closing the Achievement Gap
episodes.description: Ronald Ferguson, faculty director of the Achievement Gap Initiative, discusses his upcoming PPE Institute 'Closing the Achievement Gap: Strategies for Excellence with Equity.'

episodes.title: Making Global Local
episodes.description: Jeff Shea, Massachusetts Teacher of the Year, reflects on his craft and examines his focus on global education in the classroom.

episodes.title: What Excellent Community Colleges Do
episodes.description: Josh Wyner, author of 'What Excellent Community Colleges Do' examines the characteristics of high performing community colleges and how they prepare all students for success.

episodes.title: Revisiting "Repairing the Breach" : The Way Forward for African-American Males
episodes.description: Dr. Bobby William Austin, the developer of the initiative and editor of the report reflects on the 2014 RTB Conference.

episodes.title: The Internet-Based Public High School
episodes.description: Julie Young, president and CEO of Florida Virtual School, examines the history and growth of the first statewide Internet-based public high school in the United States

episodes.title: M. Night Shyamalan's School Sense
episodes.description: M. Night Shyamalan, filmmaker and author of “I Got Schooled,” shares his unique journey as a curious, education reform outsider looking for data informed answers on how to close America's education gap.

episodes.title: Stuck In Place: Racial Inequality in America
episodes.description: Patrick Sharkey, associate professor at New York University, discusses urban neighborhoods and the persistence of racial inequality --analyzed through the lens of his new book "Stuck in Place" and the upcoming Askwith Forum.

episodes.title: President McCartney's Big Year
episodes.description: Kathleen McCartney, president of Smith College and former dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education, reflects on an exciting year involving a new job, book, and Twitter account.

episodes.title: Wendy Kopp: A Candid Conversation
episodes.description: Wendy Kopp, CEO and Co-Founder of Teach for All, candidly reflects on her experiences leading Teach for All and Teach for America, with thoughts on the future of both organizations.

episodes.title: The Next 40 Years of Child and Family Policy
episodes.description: Hiro Yoshikawa, professor of globalization and education at NYU, discusses his new co-edited book, 'Improving the Odds For America's Children' and its tie in with an upcoming Askwith Forum celebrating 40 Years of the Children's Defense Fund.

episodes.title: 10 Minutes with Temple Grandin
episodes.description: Temple Grandin, world famous animal scientist and autism activist, sheds insight into the way she thinks, reflects on the state of autism awareness, and even reveals her favorite Claire Danes movie.

episodes.title: Schools in a Broken State
episodes.description: Sarah Dryden-Peterson, assistant professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, reflects on how education systems fare during periods of great turmoil and strife within a country.

episodes.title: Examining the Common Core
episodes.description: John King Jr., commissioner of education of the State of New York, shares his perspective on the common core --its perils, pitfalls, and opportunities.

episodes.title: Unlocking the Immunity to Change
episodes.description: Robert Kegan, professor at HGSE, discusses the mechanics, challenges, and excitement in teaching his new HarvardX course called, "Unlocking the Immunity to Change."

episodes.title: Restoring Opportunity in Education
episodes.description: Greg Duncan, co-author of the HEPG book "Restoring Opportunity" discusses the crisis of inequality and the challenge for American education in a historical and practical context.

episodes.title: A Conversation with Beverly Daniel Tatum
episodes.description: Beverly Daniel Tatum, president of Spelman College, re-examines the expression of Martin Luther King's "dream" for America, while redefining the dreams we have for ourselves, our communities, and our world.

episodes.title: Incubating #Edtech
episodes.description: Eileen Rudden, co-founder of LearnLaunch, reflects on the state of entrepreneurship and ed tech - with anticipation for LearnLaunch's annual conference in Boston on February 28th.

episodes.title: Can Love be Taught?
episodes.description: Richard Weissbourd, lecturer on education at HGSE, discusses whether love can be effectively taught in schools, reflects on the state of sex-ed, and examines where love is best modeled in the media.

episodes.title: Mayor Menino's Education Legacy
episodes.description: Thomas Menino, former mayor of Boston, reflects with HGSE's Rick Weissbourd on his leadership role in helping reshape Boston schools and shepherding education policy over the past two decades.

episodes.title: HarvardX: A Year Later
episodes.description: Justin Reich, HarvardX research fellow, examines the effectiveness of edX's open online courses through quantitative and qualitative research.

episodes.title: LGBT Activism Abroad
episodes.description: Pedro Robledo, one of the leaders of the LGBT movement in Argentina, shares his deeply personal story of equal rights, education activism, and role in the adoption of quality bullying legislation in his country.

episodes.title: A Reading Revolution
episodes.description: Jessica Marshall, chief strategy officer at LightSail Ed, explains how an adaptive, tablet-based literacy platform is revolutionizing how students are gaining 21st century skills.

episodes.title: The Tutors
episodes.description: Michael Lombardo, CEO of Reading Partners, shares his organization's 'secret sauce' for closing the reading achievement gap.

episodes.title: Making the Rounds
episodes.description: Lee Teitel, author of the book "School-Based Instructional Rounds" shares his evolving research on one of the most innovative and powerful approaches to improving teaching and learning.

episodes.title: Learning Outside the Box
episodes.description: Gerald A. Lieberman, author of "Education and the Environment" provides an innovative guide to creating a new type of environmental education that combines standards-based lessons with community investigations and service learning projects.

episodes.title: edX Marks the Spot
episodes.description: Anant Agarwal, president of edX, discusses common misconceptions with online learning, new models for leadership, and how social media will play a critical role in the future of digital learning communities.

episodes.title: The Ed Reform Menu
episodes.description: Helen Janc Malone, editor of the book, "Leading Educational Change: Global Issues, Challenges, and Lessons on Whole-System Reform" discusses the collaborative process of editing a book with diverse authors and opinions about education reform.

episodes.title: What's Happening With Vegas
episodes.description: Emiliana Vegas, chief of the education division at the Inter-American Development Bank examines the transformative relationship between banking and education in developing countries, while reflecting on her time at HGSE as a student.

episodes.title: Stretching the Higher Education Dollar
episodes.description: Andrew Kelly, co-editor of the book, "Stretching the Higher Education Dollar" shares insights into the future of higher education and explains how true reform can take place.

episodes.title: Understanding a Bully
episodes.description: Elizabeth Englander, author of the book "Bullying and Cyberbullying" discusses what every educator needs to know about this subject.

episodes.title: How Learning Can Click
episodes.description: Sari Factor, CEO of Edgenuity, discusses the future of blended learning as it relates to improving schools and districts across the country.

episodes.title: Lessons from "The Watsons Go To Birmingham"
episodes.description: Randy Testa, vice president for education at Walden Media discusses the educational and historical power of Walden Media's new film, "The Watsons Go to Birmingham."

episodes.title: Immigration Policy's Impact on Education
episodes.description: Roberto Gonzales, assistant professor at HGSE discusses his research on the impact of immigration policy as it relates to educational success in our country.

episodes.title: Preventing 'Summer Melt'
episodes.description: Lindsay Page and Ben Castleman, education researchers, discuss the effects of "summer melt" and share resources on what they're doing to help prevent it.

episodes.title: A Conversation with Dean James Ryan
episodes.description: James Ryan, dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Education reflects on his vision for HGSE, the role of education schools, and whether he roots for the Red Sox or Yankees.

episodes.title: Education As a Matter of Survival
episodes.description: Jeffrey Sachs, economist and director of The Earth Institute at Columbia University, shares his thoughts on the importance of strengthening education in an increasingly crowded, globalized world.

episodes.title: The Maine Man on Campus
episodes.description: Richard Hopper, president of Kennebec Valley Community College, reflects on his time at the "Harvard Seminar for New Presidents" and names his 'bucket list' commencement speaker.

episodes.title: The Legacy of Mr. James Meredith
episodes.description: James Meredith, civil rights activist and author, reflects on his life's work, legacy, and solutions for improving Mississippi schools.

episodes.title: 20 Minutes with Noam Chomsky
episodes.description: Noam Chomsky, linguist and philosopher, discusses Paulo Freire's writings, the future of online learning, and the things in the world he doesn't know.

episodes.title: The Future of Early Childhood Education
episodes.description: Jack Shonkoff, director of the Center on the Developing Child at Harvard University, provides insight into the future of early childhood education in America and what he hopes it will look like.

episodes.title: The Allure of Order
episodes.description: Jal Mehta, associate professor at HGSE, reflects on our country's troubled quest to remake schooling.

episodes.title: A Real Wise Guy
episodes.description: Karl Pillemer, author of the book, "30 Lessons for Living: Tried and True Advice from the Wisest Americans" reflects on what he's learned from discussions with older Americans.

episodes.title: How Can Schools Best Support Immigrant Students?
episodes.description: Michael Sadowski, author of the book, 'Portraits of Promise" shares the perspective and voices of successful immigrant students from across the country.

episodes.title: Howard Gardner's Greatest Hits
episodes.description: Howard Gardner, professor at the Harvard Ed School, reflects on his academic "greatest hits" and shares insight on where he does his best thinking.

episodes.title: The San Diego Superintendent Story
episodes.description: Richard Lee Colvin, author of the book 'Tilting at Windmills' shares his thoughts on school reform, San Diego, and America’s race to renew public education.

episodes.title: How to Discuss Tragedy with Children
episodes.description: Rick Weissbourd and Betsy Groves, HGSE faculty and experts in the field of children psychology, outline tips for how both parents and teachers can properly discuss with their kids the meaning and impact of the recent tragedy in Boston.

episodes.title: Sticks and Stones
episodes.description: Emily Bazelon, author of the book "Sticks and Stones" shares insight into writing about bullying while reflecting on her own experience with it.

episodes.title: The Education Storyteller
episodes.description: John Merrow, education correspondent for PBS NewsHour, reflects on why this is both the best of times and the worst of times in education journalism.

episodes.title: Getting the Big Picture
episodes.description: Elliot Washor, cofounder of Big Picture Learning, and collaborator Charlie Mojkowski discuss their new book, "Leaving to Learn: Designing a Student Experience that Reduces Dropouts and Produces Deep Engagement in Learning."

episodes.title: The End of Exceptionalism in American Education
episodes.description: Jeffrey R. Henig, professor of political science and education at Columbia University, reflects on the erosion of the “special status” of education decision-making over the past 50 years.

episodes.title: Adaptive Ed Tech
episodes.description: Jessie Woolley-Wilson, President and CEO of Dreambox Learning, shares insights into the future of adaptive learning and data in education technology.

episodes.title: Girl Rising: A Conversation with Director Richard Robbins
episodes.description: Richard Robbins, director of the documentary "Girl Rising" reflects on how his film is hoping to create greater awareness around girls education across the world and launch a movement.

episodes.title: Generation Ed
episodes.description: Catharine Bellinger and Alexis Morin, co-founders of 'Students for Eduction Reform" (SFER) share their story of education entrepreneurship while students at Princeton.

episodes.title: Mrs. Edelman Makes Some Noise
episodes.description: Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, reflects on the Newtown shooting, school violence, gun control--and how above all, we must continue to protect the world's children.

episodes.title: The Presidential Advisor
episodes.description: Jon Schnur, cofounder of 'America Achieves' and 'New Leaders for New Schools' reflects on his own education story while sharing personal insights into President Obama's education policies over time.

episodes.title: Straight Talking Education
episodes.description: Rick Hess, education writer and director of education policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, reflects on his personal story of learning and his role in the education reform movement.

episodes.title: Solutions to a Segregated School System
episodes.description: Charles Willie, professor emeritus at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, reflects on the challenges of desegregating schools in Boston in the 1970's.

episodes.title: Won't Back Down
episodes.description: Daniel Barnz, director of the film "Won't Back Down" reflects on why writing/directing a movie about education was just a perfect fit.

episodes.title: The Jazz in Teaching
episodes.description: Wynton Marsalis, musician and educator, opens up on how the spirit of music informs his unprecedented series of ongoing Harvard lectures.
